Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2007 01:04PM gshoemate wrote: Yes, it does suck but you will get through it.  I had 4 AC's and it was terrible.  Treatment on Monday, I would sleep from Tuesday after Naulasta until Thursday night sometimes Friday morning.  But the following week I would feel better.  I got tired easily but I was able to return to work.  I am now on taxol and it is much easier. Just listen to your body and rest when you need to.  It will get better in time. Ginger
Posts.Title: are there ANY good days? Methusala gshoemate

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2007 04:37AM gshoemate wrote: Wow, have I been there and still have days when I don't handle it well and I am 4 months post-op.  My husband saw my scar before I did and he was nothing but supportive.  I still have days where I have a hard time looking in the mirror and I have one of those "I want my old body back" moments.  Thats when my husband calms me down and puts things back into perspective by telling me "you don't want your old body back, it was sick and could of killed you".  I think with time our minds will heal with our bodies.  I look in the mirror now and see one breast, one scar, my port sticking out and a bald head.  I just know a year from now I will see a differant person staring back and I will also have my life.  Best of luck and if you ever need to talk, feel free to PM me.  It helps to talk. Ginger
Posts.Title: accepting body after surgery 3boys4me janniexy

Posts.Content: gshoemate wrote: Just got a call at work today from my family physician's office. They got the results yesterday and want me to come see the doctor today to go over them. I'm a bit freaked out but I guess it has to be done. Now if I could just stop shaking I would be alright. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Well, looks like onto the next step gshoemate cindiedee

Posts.Content: gshoemate wrote: Boy, I didn't think chemo was going to interfere with my life this much. My son had to get his shots yesterday for school and it didn't even hit me until he got home that it could effect me. So I called the onco. office in a panic and they told me to call the pediatricians office and find out if any were live viruses. Well, one was...MMR. They told me there is a 7-14 day period where he can break out from the shot and I should call my onco. back to find out what to do. So I call them back and all they told me was to keep my distance, don't let him cough on me and don't use the same bathroom. So, does anyone else have any experience with this and suggestions on what I should do. I don't know if I should move out for the next 2 weeks or what, I just don't want to end up in the hospital with an infection of any kind but I also miss hugging and kissing my baby. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 5 year old just got immunizations...help gshoemate gshoemate

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 05:58PM gshoemate wrote: Before this whole bc thing I had such a sweet tooth but since starting chemo, sweets taste weird and i'm all about the salty.  I had such a craving for a specific chip that my husband had to order them online because I couldn't find in Florida...what a sweet hubby. At this point, I would say eat what sounds good to you, it's better then not eating at all which is what I did on AC. Ginger
Posts.Title: Craving crunchy salty chips after chemo trigeek kagaines

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2007 07:01PM - edited Oct 13, 2007 07:04PM by gshoemate You have found a place with a bunch of loving sisters. I started my journey in April when the radiologoist doing the ultrasound basically told me I would be losing a breast to cancer.  I thought my world was going to end, but here I am 6 months later and I have come further then I ever thought I could.  I had my right breast removed, just finished chemo (and i'm as bald as a baby) and will start radiation in the next month or so.  Cry when you need to, it does not mean defeat, it means your human.  This is such a roller coaster of a ride, you will need to get those fears out.  When you have your path report and you know more details you will feel more in control, and believe me, control is a good thing.  My first thought was to hide my fear and tears from my husband and children, I would cry in private, but that wasn't good for any of us and my husband felt like I was pushing him away.  You can be tough when you need to be, but you also need help, support and to vent.  Come here often and ask any question that comes to mind, these ladies are amazing.  I would also suggest reading Crazy Sexy Cancer by Kris Carr, it is a very inpirational book and has helped me stay positive and focused.  It may also be helpful to ask your doc for xanax for the anxiety.  I would of been lost without my xanax. Best of luck to you...sending hugs your way. Ginger
Posts.Title: Just Holding the Tears Back just4me Fireweed

I was just getting to the point of accepting the fact that I have breast cancer and then I will forever be lopsided since my mastectomy (wish I would of gone for a bilateral) but now I'm feeling down about this next step. I'm trying to go into it with the "I can live a normal life" while on chemo but I have been reading way to much on here about how chemo affects people and it has me terrified all over again. I almost called into work this morning because I was having major anxiety issues, thank goodness for xanax. Thanks for letting me vent. Right now i'm going to focus on packing for my upcoming Disney cruise and just enjoying life until that next step happens. Thanks again. Ginger Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: gshoemate wrote: O.K., I'm sitting here in a panic. May 4th I was diagnosed with IDC in the right breast. Had a rb mastectomy on May 9th, had PET and MRI in June and started chemo in July. I have 3 treatments left of Taxol then radiation. Here's my problem, I have pain in my left breast and I am so scared it is cancer. I can't feel any lump but my breasts are dense. The pain is very low, right where my bra comes across. At first I tried to tell myself that I was having some hormonal issues and breast tenderness because it started around the same time my period was supposed to start (but my period never came). The pain comes and goes, it's not consistant. Is it possible that I have a growth since my PET scan (which was clear except for some glowing nodes)in July? I know I have to mention it to my oncologist but I am terrified. I think I need a xanax!!!! Ginger Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2007 02:22AM gshoemate wrote: Hi Mary Jo, I would describe my experience with Neulasta as he**.  My nurses told me it would feel like flu symtems but it is much worse.  I told my Oncologist's nurse today all the problems I was having and she said that I could skip the neulasta my last 2 treatments but my doc nixed that since the last person she told that to ended up with a high fever.....I was so bummed.  I have pain in my hips, arms and my underarm area where the nodes were taken out feels like I just got out of surgery.  I did hear a nurse tell a patient that was getting her first treatment that the neulasta shot will effect areas that you have had previous troubles with.  So if you have had issues with painful joints in the past...the neulata will effect that area.  Give it a few days and see if you feel better.  I'm sure it all has to do with the neulasta...it's evil I tell you...evil. Ginger
Posts.Title: is this Neulasta bone pain? bluewillow one_special_angel2006

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2007 08:52AM - edited Oct 25, 2007 08:52AM by gshoemate Hi Barbara, just a quick message, i'm on my way out the door for my first visit with the radiologist to discuss my radiation route.  But I just wanted to tell you to not let cancer change who you are.  I had some friends that did not think I was taking it seriously because I was not curling up in a corner hiding from the world.  I was still doing my daily stuff and still laughing and joking, that is who I am and cancer will not change that.  There is a beautiful young girl that was dx with rare stage IV cancer and she is changing the way cancer is viewed, she even had a doc. on TLC called Crazy Sexy Cancer, she has a book and was on Oprah this week.  She is living life, not living cancer and that is what we all have to do. www.crazysexycancer.com Please let us know when you meet with your docs and find out more info. Ginger

Posts.Title: Core biopsy tomorrow and the panic is here. gshoemate awb

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2007 05:28AM gshoemate wrote: Hi Barbara, I am sorry that you have had to join our group but you will find the greatest support here. When I went for my mammogram and my ultrasound the radiologist was very serious, told me after the ultrasound that if the surgeon said they could save my breast get a second opionon.  He was also oh so serious.  Come to find out, it wasn't his job to tell me anything.  Even though he was right and I did lose my breast, you don't know anything about the lump found until the biopsy is done, then you will know how to fight this.  Once I met with my surgeon he went with a core biopsy, found 3 lumps (but they were somehow all joined so they were really 1) so a mastectomy was the next step.  I have never been told my stage, my docs don't believe in it because there is no such thing as a percentage of survival when we are talking about 1 person, it's 100% or nothing.  But from all my results I would say I was a stage 3.  Wait until you get your results before thinking about the next step.  Just take it one step at a time. Ginger
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: May 5, 2007 03:22PM gshoemate wrote: Panny, I can honestly tell you that I know how scared you are. I got the news yesterday that I have breast cancer. I need to have one breast removed. I am scared, I am nervous but I feel better knowing for sure what is going on in my body and know that soon will have a game plan of how to fight this. You can't fight what you don't know. Once you get to the doctor, find out what your up against, it will be easier to handle. And having the attitude that your going to die is not good for you. You need to switch that around, and fight with everything you have. Who knows, you may have nothing to fight against. But you won't know until you take that first step.

Posts.Title: Flunked the ultrasound videochicke videochicke

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 07:20PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 07:20PM by gshoemate Yes, what a great friend.  Let me share my experience.  I live in Florida and my family lives in Michigan.  However, when I was diagnosed, a time when family should come together, mine dropped off the planet.  So this board has not only been my support but my family as well. Keep in touch and let her know your there for here.  Don't let a week go by without getting in touch with her whether through email, phone call or mail.  The best thing for me was to sign up for a chemo angel..and I got 2.  They were my savor.  Every week I would hear from them through mail and they would send me little care packages.  The best one included a movie, popcorn holders, popcorn and candy for a family movie night, my kids loved it.  Just be there to listen to her fears and concerns and let her know how much you love here and are there for her.  And if you can find cheap airfare, a surprise visit would be just what the doctors ordered Ginger

Posts.Title: Chemo Port - what to expect Footsox1 gshoemate

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2007 07:44AM gshoemate wrote: Mine was put in at the time of my mastectomy. It is located right under my collar bone but some surgeons will put them in your arm. Everyone's experience will be differant. Mine sticks out alot but I am very thin and my surgeon says it really has no place to settle. It is very sensitive and I have had it since May 9th. I think most people don't experience to much trouble with it. But will have my first chemo today so I will know more about that aspect by the end of the day. I know some people have it put in a few days prior to chemo. I don't think 10 days is excessive at all, it will give it time to heal before your first chemo.
Posts.Title: Chemo Port - what to expect Footsox1 gshoemate
